catalyst.context: Solar driven conversion of CO 2 into carbonaceous chemicals is a promising strategy to mitigate greenhouse gas emission and simultaneously store renewable energy.Rational construction of heterostructured cocatalysts represents an efficient method to improve the photocatalytic activity and selectivity in CO 2 reduction.In this work, with PdAu core-shell nanostructures with tunable Au thickness as model cocatalysts, we demonstrate the synergism of surface strain and interfacial polarization for enhanced photoreduction of CO 2 into CO.According to our experimental analysis and theory simulation, resulted from the mismatch in lattice parameters between Pd core and Au shell, compressive strain on the Au surface elevates the d-band center and improves the adsorption of key intermediate COOH.Meanwhile, charge polarization, driven by the difference in electronegativity between Pd and Au, accelerates the interfacial charge transfer and increases the electron density on Au surface.It is found that both effects are dependent on the thickness of Au shell.As a result, three-atom-thick Au shell dramatically boosts the overall efficiency in CO 2 -to-CO conversion with an impressive activity of 166.3 mol g cat -1 h -1 and selectivity of 90.6.This study can be viewed as a means of designing photocatalysts via the simultaneous control of surface catalytic reactivity and interfacial charge transfer in cocatalysts.

reduction reaction (Fig. S10 andS11).It can be seen that the barrier for the hydrogenation of CO 2 to COOH on Au(100) surface without strain is 1.74 eV, which decreases to 1.49 and 1.20 eV under light source.context: Solar driven conversion of CO 2 into carbonaceous chemicals is a promising strategy to mitigate greenhouse gas emission and simultaneously store renewable energy.Rational construction of heterostructured cocatalysts represents an efficient method to improve the photocatalytic activity and selectivity in CO 2 reduction.In this work, with PdAu core-shell nanostructures with tunable Au thickness as model cocatalysts, we demonstrate the synergism of surface strain and interfacial polarization for enhanced photoreduction of CO 2 into CO.According to our experimental analysis and theory simulation, resulted from the mismatch in lattice parameters between Pd core and Au shell, compressive strain on the Au surface elevates the d-band center and improves the adsorption of key intermediate COOH.Meanwhile, charge polarization, driven by the difference in electronegativity between Pd and Au, accelerates the interfacial charge transfer and increases the electron density on Au surface.It is found that both effects are dependent on the thickness of Au shell.As a result, three-atom-thick Au shell dramatically boosts the overall efficiency in CO 2 -to-CO conversion with an impressive activity of 166.3 mol g cat -1 h -1 and selectivity of 90.6.This study can be viewed as a means of designing photocatalysts via the simultaneous control of surface catalytic reactivity and interfacial charge transfer in cocatalysts.
